newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Korean car plant opens in Russia.
newsitem.headline: Korean car plant opens in Russia.

text.p: Russian Premier Viktor Chernomyridn on Friday drove a Korean car off an assembly line here in a project that may eventually be worth $1.2 billion.
About 30,000 cars will be built at the Kia Motors-Baltika plant this year, officials said.
"We do not have to import everything," Chernomyrdin said at the factory inauguration.
"We are ready, in our government, to work with foreign firms like the one represented here," he said.
Russian consumers badly need new cars, but they need jobs, which Chernomyrdin promised, even more.
Federation of Independent Trade Unions President Mikhail Shmakov said the 1.2 million roubles ($200) monthly wage at the factory would be twice the regional average.
The factory expect to raise production to 80,000 cars within three or four years, with 65 percent of parts made locally in three to five years, Kia-Baltika chief executive Vladimir Ryndin said.

But the $1.2 billion total cost of the venture cited by the International Foundation for Promoting Investment and Privatisation (Interprivatiszatsia), the Russian holding company which owns all the Kia-Baltika factories, will only be met when profits are reinvested, additional new funds found and parts factories built.
So far only about $54 million has been invested, Ryndin said.
